definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To stretch out, open out (a material etc.) so that it more fully covers a given area of space. [from 13th c.]
examples: He spread his newspaper on the table.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To extend (individual rays, limbs etc.); to stretch out in varying or opposing directions. [from 13th c.] simple past and past participle of spread
examples: I spread my arms wide and welcomed him home.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To disperse , to scatter or distribute over a given area. [from 13th c.]
examples: I spread the rice grains evenly over the floor.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To proliferate ; to become more widely present, to be disseminated . [from 13th c.]
( transitive ) To disseminate ; to cause to proliferate , to make (something) widely known or present. [from 14th c.]
examples: The missionaries quickly spread their new message across the country.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To take up a larger area or space; to expand , be extended. [from 14th c.]
examples: I dropped my glass; the water spread quickly over the tiled floor.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To smear , to distribute in a thin layer. [from 16th c.]
examples: She liked to spread butter on her toast while it was still hot.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cover (something) with a thin layer of some substance, as of butter. [from 16th c.]
examples: He always spreads his toast with peanut butter and strawberry jam.

definitions.definition: To prepare; to set and furnish with provisions.
( intransitive , slang ) To open one’s legs , especially for sexual favours. [from 20th c.]

definitions.definition: To speedread ; to recite one's arguments at an extremely fast pace.

main_definition: ( intransitive , transitive , debating slang ) To speedread ; to recite one's arguments at an extremely fast pace.
